Ant mobile can look up for any entity, provided it exists in the information system. Some examples of querys are "I123", "Nicky Minaj", …
General search. ANT decides what is more relevant for the provided query
University staff. Including teachers, researchers and external collaborators (among others)
Rooms, laboratories and auditoriums, with or without computers or lab equipment
This query must not be empty
There is no menu for this restaurant…
Universidade do Porto in the news
Search for curricular units along with their planning

Ant Mobile was developed by two devoted programmers looking for a better way to search for people and resources in complex information systems.
This app consists of two main blocks: the app itself and ANT, the platform that indexes the available information on a daily basis. 

ANT is currently being developed (and tested) at the InfoLab (infolab.fe.up.pt) by José Devezas. It consists of a research platform in the domain of entity oriented search. In this particular case, ANT is focused on the University of Porto's information system. It aims at promoting research in this field by providing a basis for integration with other research fields such as indexing strategies, ranking algorithms and, among others, query suggestion. You can check the latest version at ant.fe.up.pt. 

ANT Mobile is the app itself. It started as an idea of solving the particular issue of searching for anything at the University of Porto wherever you are. It resorts to the ANT infrastructure to fetch the search results and show the end users a mobile friendly interface and interaction. Besides that, it also shows additional (hopefully useful) information about the park occupation and the canteens' menu. 

We (very, like 10 minutes ago)recently got a talented designer to handle some interface issues that we were constantly facing. Her name is Ana Reis (big thanks to her), and you can check her portfolio at cargocollective.com/RochaReisDesign. 

Should you need to get mor information, feel free to get in touch with us at the InfoLab, room I123.
